text: 22 ounce bottle. Thanks Keith1 Pours dark brown with a decent tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, fruit, and alcohol. Taste is roasted malt, dark fruit, caramel, brown sugar, and alcohol. Nice!

Back-rate: Poured a dark, opaque brown with beige head. Nose was heavy on dark brown sugar, plums, cocoa and some earthiness. Slick mouthfeel with nice carbonation. Flavor held true to the nose with a lack of sweetness from the brown sugar component that I was worried would make it a bit cloying. Awesome brew.

Bottle shared by Jay & Dr Silverworm. Poured clear dark brown color with an average frothy brown head that lasted with good lacing. Good toasted dark malt and dark sugar aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth thick texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy sweet toasted malt flavor with a medium to heavy smooth dark sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Very good doppelbock.

22oz bottle, thanks to Jay. Shared with local raters. Very dark brown color. Good thin light brown head, leaves good lace. Some dark chocolate, dark fruit, light vinous notes... A lot better than expected for (what I believe is) a 3 year old doppelbock, holding up pretty good it seems. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, lighter carbonation. Kind of creamy, with a dry finish. Nice dark chocolate notes, moderate bigger bitter taste, less sweet. Alcohol is well-blended. Loving the dark chocolate finish on this; lightly toasty malt. Impressive stuff, much better than expected.

22 oz bottle shared by DrSilverworm via Jay. Pours a dark brown to black color with a small beige head. The aroma and flavor had a great chocolate character, dark fruits, some roasted malt, molasses, medium plus body, smooth, good drinking beer. This is one of the better doppelbocks that Ive had (especially since Chris thinks the bottle is around 3 years old).

Bomber to snifter (shared by DrSilverworm). Looks good; a fairly opaque dark brown with beige lacing. Smells of dark malt, chocolate, and mild roast. Tastes like it smells with more chocolate. Nice and smooth on the palate. A good example of the style.

A: Dark Brown Hue, Passes No Light, Mild Brown Head Ring, Minimal Lacing

S: Mild Bourbon, Molasses, Chocolate, Sweet Malts

T: Molasses, Sweet Malts, Chocolate, Mild Bourbon

M: Average Carbonation, Medium to Full Bodied, Semi Sweet, Mildly Boozy, Mildly Oily

Overall, a pretty nice but mildly boozy dopplebock.

Bottle @ Christers. Pours black with a small light brown head. Aroma of malt, caramel, grain, bread, brown sugar. Flavor is malt, caramel, dark fruits, bread, booze. Medium body, soft carbonation, warming alcoholic finish. 231013

Bottle @ Christer. Almost pitch black, small tan head that disappear fast, some lacing. Aroma, malty, bread, cereal, roasted notes, caramel, . Taste, roasted malts, bread, caramel, dark fruits, hops, brown sugar, . Dry aftertaste.

Bottle @ Aarhus tasting. Almost black with a small beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dried fruit, a little roasted malt and alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish with warming alcohol. 231013

Bottle. Almost black with small beige head. Aroma is malt, chocolate, dusty, toasted, little toffee and soy. Flavour is malt, caramel, soy, chocolate, medium sweet, nut, toasted, bread, vegetable and dusty.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma and taste are rich fruits, caramel, malt, hops, spices and hops.
pours dark, clear brown. very small white/brown foam. smells smoked ( hah...) taste is bitter, smoked, but not too extreme . meh.. one of the less traumatizing smoked beers :)

Thx! to Kraddel. 66 cl. bottle shared by Kraddel. Incredible label!!! Appearance is blackish, copper hue, almost no mocha head. Nose is semi-mellow smoked, lightly musty, smoked malts, light olives, Taste is nicely smoked, typical dopplebock, light soy, light meat sauce, bitter smoked, bitter malts, bitter spices, thick malts, light vegetable, hint chocolate, Drinks nicer from the bottle. Body is typical dopplebock, substantially fuller than usual.

22 oz. bottle, sent from St. Fun (thanks Josh), pours a deep dark brown / near-black with a medium beige head. Aroma of toasted nuts, a little roast, some unsweetened chocolate, and a considerable hop punch. Flavour brings out loads of dark fruits, toasted nuts, and toffee. Almost like a stout, but a lot softer and fruitier. Full-bodied and very round, finishing very fruity. Good stuff, but nothing extraordinary.

Duft a kaffe og sprit, kul sort lys brun skum, smag ristet malt, sød, kaffe, candis, choko eftersmag med kaffe

Free Føroyar!!!

Bottle. Dark brown close to black with a small beige head. Aroma is chocolate, rum soaked raisins, cocoa, roasted malt. Taste is medium/heavy sweet and light/medium bitter. Medium body, oily/watery texture, near flat carbonation. Stout/bock.

1st February 2012Opaque black beer, short lived tan head. The palate has some body and is crispy. Creamy thick malt with a touch of molasses. Pleasant fruit underneath,  a little cherry. Mild minerals in the smooth finish. Nice beer but lacking the usual 3F wow factor.

A thick imperial like dopplebock.  Big chocolate and sweeter side, with understated bitterness.  A big beer, very dangerously drinkable.  Deep brown bodied with lots of retained head.
Bottle in trade from (fill in blank when I remember).
@ Mikkeller Bar: Jag är vanligvis ingen fan av bocköl, men denna har en fin balans av malt och sötma vilket inte för den för söt. Trevlig fyllig vätska med tydlig kolaton.

Bottle shared with the fellas after Day Two of the Copenhagen Beer Celebration. Pours red-black with a sturdy, beige foam head. Pretty strong dark fruit aroma, some straight dirt. Big sweet flavor, nice cocoa, dirty earth, chocolate, dark raisins, some ripe grapes, prunes and dates. Medium to full bodied with fine carbonation. Mild warmth in the finish with lots of rich chocolate, dark fruits, faint earthy bitterness, lots of dark toasty sugars, dates and figs. Very solid. Good darkness here. Rich and well balanced with lots of depth. Great.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar, November 2012.

Dark brown with a medium head. Aroma and taste of malt, toffee, some "cardboard", dark fruit and brown sugar. The mouthfeel was thick.

22oz bottle, purchased at the brewpub a while back.  Pours a deep, dark, coffee brown with a tan head.  Aroma is malty, roasty, molasses, dark fruit.  Medium on the palate with soft carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, Some cereal, with a sweet, molasses finish.  Another tasty beer from FFF.

22 oz bomber courtesy of Todd.  Pours a pitch black cola with a medium sized light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, prunes, plums and hints of figs.  Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, prunes, plums, figs and barley.  Another winner from 3 FFFs.
Dark brown pour with a wispy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, some light brown sugar, and some toffee.  Flavor is a bit sweet, some raisin bread, caramel malts, roasted nuts.

Bottle at the Mikkeller Bar Copenhagen. A Doppelbock but not exactly what I was expecting. Not a great head and no lacing, but an awesome toffee caramel flavour with a lingering slightly fruity and soft aftertaste. Not a cheap beer but worth the expense. Would certainly drink again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle shared at Mikkeller bar.  Pours dark brown with a tiny tan ring head.  Aroma of malt, toffee, vanilla, roasted malt and a touch of dark fruit.  Flavour is over medium sweet, light bitter.  Mouthfeel is sticky and slightly oily.  Full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar. Deep sludgy brown with no head. The nose is deep toffee and chocolate, some coffee beans and cherry. Malty brown sugar sludge. The taste is chewy chocolate bars and light caramel, some brown sugar with a lightly hot finish. The bodys slightly thin and watery. A bit boozy, too. Overall, decent. But not a top effort from FFF.

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar. It pours almost black, with a thick tan head. The nose is meat, caramel, toasted coconut, almond and cocoa. The taste is caramel, roasted malt, sweet fruit, filter coffee, meat, toasted coconut and cocoa, with dryness in the finish. Medium body, moderate carbonation and sticky mouth-feel. Not quite as complex as I hoped for. So-so.

Pours a thick dark brown with a small tan head and is almost opaque in the glass.  The aroma is sweet milk chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and vanilla.  The taste is sweet, malty, and roasty with a long bitter finish.  Nice oily texture and a smooth mouthfeel.  Another great beer from 3Floyds and easily one of the best Doppelbocks Ive ever had.
22oz bottle. Poured a black color, brown edges, and a small sized off white head. Aromas of caramel, nutty, chocolate, ashy, and roast. Tastes of caramel, chocolate, some roast, and smoke.

22oz bottle thanks to exiled.
Deep ruby brown pour with some tan head.  Nose of dark fruit, roasted malt, and chocoalte.  Flavor is smooth and malty with a fudgey finish.  Starting to think Three Floyds can do any style out there.
Pours a very dark brown with a beige head. Smells of perfume. Sweet with aromas of burnt malts, liquorish and rye bread. Hints of pepper. Soft carbonation. Full bodied.

First of all, this is more like a Baltic Porter than any Doppelbock Ive ever laid my lips on.  That said, this beer is unreal; cellared for 10+ months in ideal conditions.  Pours opaque black with a thin dark brown head that quickly fades to a ring.  Aroma is big roasty chocolate, raisins, massive earthiness, coffee, some clean malt lager character, signature FFF green hoppiness.  Taste is rich dark chocolate, raisin, coffee, some caramel and toffee, earthy spicy hoppiness.  Body is full and chewy, medium carbonation, long roasty finish.  Overall, this kind of reminds me of Alpha Klaus if it were brewed with lager yeast.
Bottle.  Chocolate malt and ash aroma.  Opaque black color with minimal head.    Very sweet chocolate malt and moderately bitter ashy/herbal flavor.  Nice body.  Excellent.
bottle thanks to exiled.  black pour with a cream head.  nose is chocolate, syrup, caramel, and faint smoke.  smooth on the palate, deep rich malts, caramel, and a light smoke finish.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar, during 3Floyds Night 2011.  Very dark brown, almost black color, small brown head. Sweet, roasted malty taste, lots of caramel and a nutty touch. Roasted malt flavours, caramel, rye. Medium bitterness. Could this be the first Doppelbock/Porter hybrid ? :D

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma is full of heavy chocolate and roasted malt. I also get a little cream character in the aroma. While it smells delicious, it doesnt really smell like a doppelbock.

The flavor is similar. The dominant flavors are chocolate and roasted malt, but there is also a little dark fruit hidden in the background. The alcohol is present in the flavor and the aroma, but the beer is still easy to drink and quite enjoyable. 

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

In short: A sweet sticky dark beer.  Good but nothing special.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed approximately 6 months after first bottle rating.  Bottle sent to me by Sherm1016, thanks a lot Todd
The look: Near black body topped by a very small dark beige head
In long: Nose is mostly liquorice, figs a bit of rubber and also some dark hard candies.  Taste is very straightforward, fruit cake with an extra of dates and figs, chalky yeast, soy sauce, caramel.  Very cake-like maltiness, a bit oily, a bit sticky.  This is a very sticky sweet beer, I know many doppelbocks are, but this one just didnt have the complexity and richness to match its sweetness.  I drank a full bottle but I was really happy to move to something else once the bottle was finished.  Also I like to pretend this beer was made in my honor.  Creepy, Creeper.  Close enough.

(22oz bomber thanks to Exiled) clear ruby with thick very dark brown head and excellent coating of the glass. Nose of graham cracker, cream, smooth chocolate. Taste of raisin, dry semi-sweet chocolate, rich, a bit fudgey, this is nice! Creamy linger, excellent.

pours a brown color, no head, no lace.  nose is roasty coffee, chocolate with a trace of fruitiness.  roasty malt in the flavor, but not much else.  medium bodied, clean finish.  perhaps a bit too light and sweet for me.  my notes also say "insert clever remark here", but my wittiness fails me.

Botella. Deep dark brown colour with a nice beige like head. Pleasant aroma of roasted like malt and caramel with chocolate and liqourice, sweet. Good filling mouthfeel. Flavour has roasted malt, caramel,sweet like,  chocolate, liqourice and a pleasant bitterness.
Pour is a very dark brown with ruby edges.  Light tan head and drippy lace.  Dark fruit, toffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor has lots of tobacco and chocolate malts, caramel, toffee

(22oz bottle, courtesy of Exiled)  Pours a mahogany body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, and cocoa.  Flavor of caramel, vinous, cocoa, anise, toffee, dates, and toasted grain.

0.65l bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen shared with ClubGonzo and the rest of Bergen Tasting Crew. Pours a dark dark brown body with a small fading creamy chocolate head. Aroma is sweet and dark caramelly. Notes of dark fruits, light roasted malts,  some thin chocolate and perhaps even some thin coffee? Medium-bodied, has a thick and oily mouthfeel and the carbonation level is average. Tastes quite nice. Theres some strong sweet notes but its never on the border of tipping in to TO sweet, dark and salty licorice, also some notes of dark malts. Can hardly notice the relatively high abv. but its leaving a nice warming feeling.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy caramel aroma with hints of dark fruit. Fruity malty caramel and dark fruit flavor with hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel and dark fruit finish.

Bottle from Ølbutikken, shared with Palme and friends. Near-black (VERY near) brown body, medium beige head. Aroma is deep malty notes with salty licorice and some nuts scattered around. Nice. Taste is equally deep malty coffee tones, with hints of salty licorice and faint traces of salmiac. Hints of walnut in the finish. The warming alcohol is masterly hidden on the palate, which is smooth and full-bodied. A very good dobbelbock (which is almost a borderline imp stout) from 3F.

Bottled. Very dark brown coloured. Has a dense brownish head. aroma of liqourice, caramel, bread, roast and coffee. Its the same in the flavour. Very very roasty and coffeish. Medium to full bodied. Has a dry and somewhat fruity roastiness in the end.

Bottled. Quite much pitch black colouor, small brown head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malts, and mild toffeeish notes. Flavour is coffee, chocolate, roasted malts and mild toffeeish notes. Pleasantly balanced. doublebock?

Bottled 650ml (PBF)
Dark opaque brown color, small off-white head. Licorice, candy, coffee, dark malts in the nose. Full-bodied. Licorice, cold coffee, rye, extreme roastyness.Suprisingly short finish. Feels less alcoholic than 9 %.
65cl, no mention of ABV, new exclusive American brew Anno 2010, thx to Jeppe!, complex brew, roasted and malty, heavy, not balanced, hazy, small head, good brew, yet expensive!

Fra flaske, dufter dejligt af karamel svagt ristet malt, flot sort med lysebrunt skum .. Smager dejligt af karamel, ristet malt , lakrids... Eftersmagen er let sprittet .... Men en dejlig doppelbock :)

Bottle. Pours black with a creamy tan head. The aroma is roasted malt, light chocolate, light smoke and some liquorice. The flavour is quite roasted with notes of bread, toasted caramel and some liquorice. The alcohol is well hidden. Smooth body. Light hoppy and malty finish.
Crushed with Honkeybra.  Certainly not your average dopplebock.  Very malty, kinda dark fruity and roasty with a nice, bitter hop finish.  Pretty spectacular.

Bottled. An almost black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma has notes of rye, malt, alcohol, and nuts. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, caramel, alcohol, roasted malt, and hops, leading to a bitter hoppy finish. Not your traditional German Doppelbock.

22 fl oz bottle, courtesy of Ungstrup. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Aroma is dark roasted malt and breadish. Liqourice and dark roasted malt flavoured. Slight bitter and dark roasted malt and lasting liqourice flavoured. Lingering dark chocolate and liqourice.

Bottle
Courtesy exiled. Pours a very dark brown color with a nice rosy highlight. Bubbly brown head. Aroma is smoky with roasted malts and a tad bit of chocolate. Flavor is roasted malts with dark bitter chocolate. Finishes chocolatey and dark heavy malts.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar, Cph.
Pours deep, deep black with a lovely, staying, creamy, beige head. Aroma is sweet, chocolate, mild fruity, some caramel. Medium carbonation, lovely creamy palate. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, mild caramel, grassy. Very elegant, very balanced. Yummy.

Bottle 65 cl. Pours an almost opaque black with a light brown head - looks mostly like an Imperial Stout. Distinct licorice aroma, some alcohol and pumpernickel. Very solid body, roasted maltiness, nuts and pumpernickel. Has a discreet bitterness in the finish. Id call this a Stout/Bock fusion. 250511

Bottle 22fl.oz. @ Mikkeller Bar, Viktoriagade 8BC, kld., DK-1655 Copenhagen, Denmark.Clear dark brown colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to light beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, oyster stout alike, moderate caramel, light sugar. Flavour is light heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration, dark malt, sugar, sweet malt. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20110525]
Nose is heavy malt, yeast and cane sugar, then a coffee note, feel is mediumbroad, carb is mediumlow, taste is early sweet rosehip, some rotten fruit and red apple, then alcohol and wet hops finish.
bottle. Pitxh dzrk, smooth loght brown head. 4  roasted aroma. Licorice, malts. Dry hops, subdued. 7 flavor is roasted stuff, malts , caramel, super well balanced and very tasty8

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar.
Dark brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet aroma of caramel, dried fruits, rye bread and alcohol.
Sweet flavour of caramel, bread and dried fruits.
Sweet finish.
Bottle at MikkellerBAR. Black - brown head. Coffee. Nice malty. Berries. Nutty. High malty. Fruity. Light bitterness. Light ryebread. Dry finish. Nice - doppelbock ???  Baltic Porter !?!?

Bottle purchased at the brewery over Christmas and shared at a recent tasting. Served in a snifter.

Pours a dark chestnut brown with a pretty good tan head. After the initial pour, the head dies down somewhat quickly but leaves some nice lacing and eventually settles into a moderately-thick collar. The nose is really quite sweet straight from the start with some really nice notes of chocolate, dark fruits, and toffee. The taste follows along this path, though isnt quite as sweet or complex as the nose. Very smooth. Good light chocolate notes and a bit of caramelized dates. Medium body with good carbonation. A nice example of the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-16-2011

Bottle Dark brown lager with a small, creamy, khaki head. Great retention. The bouquet is an outright mocha-bomb  I love it. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and relaxed carbonation. Crusted port and dark, unsweetened chocolate step forth in the flavor with gooey caramel in close pursuit. Sweet caramel and dark chocolate finish mild bitterness hangs on a good while. Bottle courtesy of 50belair. Thanks, Matt!
Bottle thanks to thetomg.  Clear dark brown pour with a faint white head.  Dark fruit and chocolate nose.  The taste is chocolate malt, plums, figs, raisins.  Very nice doppelbock...

This poured a medium to darker brown with a beige head. Aroma was darker malts, light dark fruits,a nd some smoke. Flavor was very smooth sweet chocolate, some roasted malts, and a good amount of smoke as well. Like most three floyds beers, a bit off style, but still a good beer overall.

Poured into a pilsner glass (though after the fact a snifter might have been a better option).

3.5 A: Pours black. About three fingers of creamy light brown head with below average retention and just a small ring of lacing.

3.5 S: Good amount of roastiness in this with semi-sweet chocolate making a big appearance as well. Some faint caramel, but overall fairly dry. Malts can be described as grainy, if anything. Grassy hoppiness Not bad, but needs some strength.

4.0 T: Unlike the nose, the taste is big and bold. Roasted malts, milk chocolate, medium roast coffee each exhibit plenty of force. Secondarily, there is a touch of smoke, some lactose-like sourishness, caramel, and dark fruits. Again, grassy hops. Pretty good, borderline 4.5.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Creamy, but could be more so and super smooth.

4.0 D: This is a pretty good beer and is basically an imperial stout brewed with lager yeast. Good taste, no off-flavors, and highly drinkable.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-20-2011 21:42:52

Served from bottle.  Deep black with brown/red hues.  Sufficiently malty aroma with some dark fruit, wood.  Initial coffee, roasted malt flavor, followed by dark fruits, plum, slight acidity.  Nice even carbonation.  A very good dark doppelbock that bucks the style parameters.  Match of a baltic and a doppelbock.  Very nice.

Bomber thanks to thetomG on BA.  The Creeper pours a dark brown color with a large tan head that soon fades to a half finger size then settles at that.  Roasty aroma with malt balls, toffee, and dark fruit.  Smells very nice.  Big full flavor - you could convince me that this was a good German doppelbock.  Rather roasty with slight coffee notes, molasses, toffee, fig and other dark fruits.  Not too sweet.  Medium-full bodied with carbonation on the lively side.  This is very good.  Id be all over the creeper like Chris Hansen.
22 oz bottle. from Lushawn (I think).  Soy sauce brown/black.  Nose malty and alcohol.  Big fuzzy mouth.  Dark malt taste.  Sharp tartness to deep dark fruit.  Roasted.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2011 This was quite the taste. Toasty nuts and morning bread and jam with a surprisingly smooth ending. Light in texture. I could have a few of these at a time, but thats why they call it the Creeper because it sneaks up on. You will feel the 9% trust me.

Dark brown pour with a tan head. Roasted malty nose, bready, kind of nutty, and alcohol. Caramel, dried fruits, nutty, malts, a bit hoppy, and a touch of alcohol. Mouth is thin and bitter with a warming alcohol finish.

Bottle via lagunitasfan via lushawn via god knows where.  Pours a nice dark color underneath and full and frothy above.  salty, nutty, alcoholic, port-wine-like nose.  Malty, sweet, and doppelbock-like flavors with nice sweet, nutty characteristics...very malty beer but hides the alcohol quite well, at least a lot better than the nose led on...though it kind of presents itself in the very late finish/aftertaste where the nutty bitterness and alcohol are all thats left.  Lots of nutty brittle flavors though...and a punch of two of some malty sweetness.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour, small light tan head.  Dark dried fruits, caramel malts, sweet sugars, raisin, and some roastiness.  A decent doppelbock, not my favorite style.  I do like the tribute to Pelican though.
Dark brown pour with tan head and lace. Dried fruit and light brown sugar. Super sweet roasted malt and dried fruit. Medium bodied with good carbonation.
Black as a stout, this was a very German flavor- bready and alcoholic, really warms your chest as it goes down. Smooth, but pretty generic. Sampled at the Nashville Beer Summit.
Shared at Nashville Beer Summit 1.0. Pours brown with a tan head. Medium bodied with steady carbonation. Flavor of dark german malts and dark fruits, with an extra spicy hop kick. Pretty solid.
1/7/10.  Bottle thanks to mlunger12. Mild malty caramel aroma with hints of cocoa.  Sweet malty flavor with a surprising amount of roasted goodness mixed with chocolate.
Pours dark brown with a dark tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit, caramel, slight smoke.  Flavor is similar, touch of smoke in the flavor as well.  Sweet, but very good beer.
good, thin, watery, bitter, umami/savory, bready, caramel, molasses, almond, vanilla, dark, white head,
22oz bottle, courtesy of Agentzero on BA. Pours black without much head, a little lacing, some sweetness on the aroma, not a bad doppelbock, I find it growing on me. Nice brew

Dark brown with a slightly reddish hue.  Ring of small dense bubbles for head.

Some roasty elements to the aroma.  Flavor is similar with some strong flavors of malt, dark fruits and maybe even a twinge of smoke. 

Lively carbonation, which was pleasant and unexpected.  Not a style I typically go for, but this one was quite tasty and Im definitely looking forward to trying it out of the bottle so I can compare.

Pours an interestingly dark brown with a noticeable viscosity and producing one finger of creamy dark tan head, dissipates quickly. Nose is interesting very malty and dextrinous with notes of leather, raisin, cocoa, and caramel. Flavor is similar, very rich with strong grainy notes and some soy sauce. Palate is coating and the body is full and coating.
Bomber. Pours black with a one inch tan head into a 1 L stein. Chocolate aroma. Caramel, toffee, and chocolate flavor. Outstanding doppelbock.

Courtesy of markwise. It pours dark brown with tan head. The aroma is an interesting mix of prunes, chocolate, raisins, brown sugar and some roasted malts. The taste is similar with prunes, figs and chocolate (which is odd interesting and fairly tasty all at the same time) mixing with dark roasted malts, a sense of coffee and then slivers of earthiness that add further interest.

The Dan Journal #422. Tasted 11/11/10. 22oz bomber. Pours rather opaque with a subtle ruby highlight. Spiraling head. Aromas of soapy hops and soggy malts. Mild undertones of anise, soy sauce and cocoa. The body is on the fuller side of medium. Mild honey notes with tangy dark berries and a creme broule sweetness. Graham crackers, fudge and dark chocolate. A sticky and cloying body with the tart taking a backseat. Such a pleasant drink! Absolutely perfect seasonal drinking with its crisp body and smooth flavors. It has both a chill and a warming tingling effervescence. As it warms, the raisins and chocolate flaovrs become more apparent. Theres a nice nuttiness and maple sugar sweetness that is off set by the bitter citrus and mild smokiness. Nice and toasty. Great stuff!

Bottle from Three Floyds. This is not really a doppelbock, more of a big ass Schwarzbier, imo. But whatever, its still pretty awesome. Pours deep brown/black with off white head. Nose is full of roast, chocolate and some dark stone fruit. Touch fruity. On taste, full of roast, which brings it into Schwarz territory. Full and roasty, full bodied for a lager and nice fruit notes. Pretty awesome beer.

Bottle, thanks to markwise for the share.  Poured a deep brown color with a thin tan head.  Rich malty nose, heavy roast, chocolate, toffee, bread, and ample dark fruity esters.  Full chewy body with a slippery mouth feel and ample carbonation.  Flavor wise, this beer as with most FFF beers suffers from a major identity crisis but in a very good way.  Theres enough roast and coffee notes that blind I would probably call this a stout but I still get that ripe dark fruit presence that I get from Doppelbocks, actually, blind I would probably think this was a European stout.  Interesting beer a kind of roasted, chocolaty, Doppelbock.

I tasted this on draft at Big Star a couple of weeks ago.  The pour was a super dark and opaque amber with an average beige head.  The nose is a lot of sweeter caramel and chocolate with some dark chocolate and roasted malt bitterness.  On the palate, this beer is pretty dense and sweet with caramel, milk chocolate, bitter dark chocolate, and some darkly roasted bitterness as well.  The body is fairly full with average carbonation and a long caramel and dark chocolate finish.

Thanks to Tooch4321 for this one in trade.  Ok, so knowing that this is an FFF beer tells me that style will be ambiguous, but it is a tad difficult to describe this beer.  Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Nose is roast, chocolate, earth, slight tobacco, and slight smoke.  Flavor is chocolate all over, roast, some coffee up front, and some pruney/ dark fruit in finish along with esters, and slight spice.  Medium-bodied and definitely diFFFerent.

Whenever someone says "no words to describe" something I like to prove them wrong by describing it.
Deep chocolate pour. Medium lacing. Chocolate, roasty nose. Lots of chocolate on the palate. Thinner mouthfeel. Nothing remotely dopplebock-like.  There, I described it. With words.  It is pretty darn good though, as long as you dont mind the fact its not what it thinks it is.

From sample pour at local December 2010 tasting.

I know nothing about doppel bocks, but I enjoyed this one.  Pours very dark brown, aroma of chocolate and roasted grain.  Chocolate is pronounced in the flavor and it has a nice lightness to it.  Bomber shared with office mates.  This sampling makes me want to try other doppel bocks, which Im sure I will.

Had on tap at the brewpub on thanksgiving weekend.

A-pours a transparent dark coloa brown with a dark tan colred head.

S-the nose is faint but very roasty in what I do get.  Roasted malts and some notes of roasted coffee.

T-the taste follows the nose but bigger.  Lots of roasted malts, lots of coffee, some notes of dark chocolate with just a hint of malt sweetness in the form of dark fruits.

M-creamy medium body that is soft on the palate and has a well carbonated finish giving it a nice clean feel on the back of the throat.

D-different than what I was expecting.  big time roasted malts with very little sweetness.  Still, this is pretty tasty, very simple and straigh tforward, with great drinkability especially for the alcohol content.

Bomber from 3F. Pours very dark brown with tan head.  Aromas of chocolate, sweet roast, toffee, and some grains. Flavors of chocolate, sweet roasted malts, bit grainy, and some dark fruits. Nice chocolaty dopplebock. Nice surprise. Almost like a foreign stout or porter.

Black pour with some faint ruby highlights at the edges and a small, dense, tan head.  Strong roasty aroma with a fair amount of dark fruit, and notes of chocolate, alcohol, and some spicy noble hops.  The flavor is heavy on roast and dark fruit, with notes of cofee, and chocolate in the middle.  Finishing with some noble hops and a crisp lager twang.  The body is creamy and full with soft carbonation and a clean lager finish.

Had on draft at FFF brewpub.  Nice work, but doppels are really not my thing.  After one, I moved on to something a little more my style.  Having said that, if you are a doppel fan, give this one a try.

Draft at Three Floyds served in a bowtie.  Pours a dark opaque brown color with a sticky tan head.  Aroma of roasted chocolate malts, brown sugar, coffee, toast, and sweet bread.  Flavor of rich sweet bready malts, cream, coffee, cocoa beans, and sugary toast.  Medium-full bodied, with mild carbonation and a sweet, roasty, gritty mouthfeel.  Hard beer to pin down, but it reminds me a lot of a northern European stout or porter.  Very interesting.

On tap at FFF, Pours very dark brown. Light tan head ,aromas of chocolate, and roaster malts. Flavor has lots of tobacco and chocolate malts, caramel, toffee.  Nice and well done as the alcohol is well hidden.CHEERS!

Draft at 3F brewpub.  Pours very dark brown.  Light tan head that is more of a ring around the glass.  Aromas of tobacco, chocolate, walnuts.  Flavor is strong: lots of tobacco and chocolate malts, caramel, toffee.  Sweetness is kept in check by a perfectly bitter roastiness.  Nice and full bodied.  A bit of alcohol creeps up in the finish.  Excellent.

draft the brewery, pours dark ruby with  tan head round the rim. the nose has chocolate, coffee, and dark fruit. flavors of dark fruit, coffee, plum skins, and nice toffee malt grain husky. i really enjoyed this one since so many american examples suck so much, this one was tasty.

Three floyds creeper. Small taster at the brewpub... Pours close to  
stoutlike with lighter brown edges and a frothy khaki head... Aroma of  
roasted malt, softer chocolate undertones and sweet malt grains...  
Flavors are of sweet roast and chocolate and finishes with sweeter  
grainy malt. Soft carbonation and a really creamy mouthfeel. A  
pleasant surprise with it being a roasty smooth chocolatey doppelbock.
7/4/8/4/15

Draft on tap at the brewpub (Munster, IN). Pours a roasty brownish hue, dark and near opaque with ruby edges that lighten up, a big frothy brownish head that laces well and cakes well. Aromas are brown sugar and caramel, toffee and toasty breads, a touch of spice and florals, faint cocoa and sweetness, bitter and sweet. Almost some licorice. Initial is medium to fuller bodied, coffee and roasty toasty malts melds into brown sugar and toffee, breads and biscuits. A decent roast and toast, almost some cherrywood smokiness, light florals, big dose of dark cocoa takes hold with toffee, caramel, biscuits. A nice touch of dark fruit smooths into the fold, touches of licorice, light florals, a faint somehow phantom spice and cherrywood. Not bad, sweeter, bigger warmth from the ABV. Complex, a bit big for me for a beer out of my normal style love. Still, wellmade and tasty.

On tap at the pub.  Dark black pour with a creamy head. A lot of roast creamy malt and piney hops.  Medium to full body. Creamy with a lot of carbonation. Fruit and chocolate roast flavors.  A little heavy in the red fruits and carbonation.  Touch of alcohol   Bitter roast finish. The bitterness is nice but it really doesnt taste much like a dopplebock. Not bad. 8/4/7/4/14

On tap a Three Floyds.  
According to the description, there are no words to describe this beer.  Ok...

Tap: Pours a deep brown with a small but lasting head and some lace. The aroma has notes of heavy roasted and slight chocolate malts, some tobacco and leather, banana and crabapple esters, with a bit of alcohol vapours. The taste is mostly malt driven with subdued fruity tones and a bit of coffee like bitterness towards the finish. Very earthy and dirty even towards the mouth feel which was chewy and slightly warming. A strange brew but I sort of enjoyed in more as it warms.

On tap at FFF and Big Star. Poured a deep brown with a slight red hue and a brown head that dissipated slowly to the edges. Aroma had a roasted coffee note with some roasted malt and a slight backing sweet chocolate note. Flavor began with sweet chocolate with a lighter coffee not and a bit of roasted malt coming out in the finish.
Draft at brewpub.  Dark maroon color.  Aroma and flavor of toasted dark bread and molasses.  Not very heavy, but still carries a lot of flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2010 Tap at fff served in bowtie.    Creamy cold coffee, bananas, with some doughy cocoa for good measure.  Blends together nicely.  Taste is doughy custard, whipped cream, bananas, lightly roasted coffee and some light complimentary booze.  Pretty good.  Banana cream pie and coffee.  Nice dessert beer.  Fff make some good beers
On tap at fff. Managed to get a glass before the keg ran out.  Not my style of beer but managed to finish a half pint of it before i left

On tap at FFF - Pours a very dark brown with amber highlights in low level lighting. Very modest beige head , with decent retention. This brew is indeed hard to describe - to me it feels like one part stout, one part doppelbock with a heavier stout element comparatively. Aroma is indeed doppelbock - reminds me of the andechser actually - a certain sweetness that is hard to describe. Mouthfeel is a little chewy - flavors are bittersweet, almost tangy german elements combined with stout characters of oatmeal and perhaps a little chocolate. Finishes a little bitter, and the abv seems to be masked fairly well.
